awd_titl_txt: Creating a STEM-capable Workforce by Supporting REU Student Participation in Professional Conferences
awd_abstract_narration:
A Research Experience for Undergraduates award has been made to the Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory (RMBL) to support the participation of undergraduate students in BIO-funded REU Site and Supplement grants at scientific conferences. This award will also enable the PI to conduct outreach activities in order to make underrepresented minority students aware of opportunities to engage in REU research as well to present their research results to a broader audience.

Approximately 150 undergraduate students each year for a period of 3 years will be supported on travel awards to conferences. Supporting student participation in scientific conferences will help create a STEM-capable workforce as students are able to network with their peers and meet future graduate program advisors and/or STEM employers. Preparation for a poster or oral presentation provides the student the opportunity to gain a deeper insight into the process of science and the significance of their work. Presenting results at a scientific conference is a capstone experience for many students, who can take advantage of the conference to explore related science topics, make connections for a possible career in science, and explore potential science career paths.  .

This project leverages existing investments in the REU program to improve undergraduate research training as well as to diversify the STEM-capable workforce.  Participation in a professional, scientific conference is an important new context for many students to engage in as part of the larger scientific community.  It gives students an opportunity to see themselves as scientists. Self-identity as a scientist is a strong positive predictor of whether students continue in science.

por.por_cntn:
The focus of this project is to provide undergraduate researchers an opportunity to present their results at professional conferences. We provided support for 379 undergraduates to present research findings at conferences. Examples of conferences include meetings hosted by the UCI Center for Neurobiology of Learning and Memory, the Society for Neuroscience, the Society for Integrative and Comparative Bioloy, the Counci on Undergraduate Research, American Geophysical Union, IEEE Mass, AISES, and the Ecological Society of America.

These activities support NSF's Intellectual Merit goals by facilitating the dissemination of cutting edge scientific research.Additionally, the activities promote Broader Impacts through development of undergraduates as scientisits. Specifically, participation in conferences helps students develop science communication skills, through engagement with science professional societies allows them to explore science s a career, and promotes retention in the sciences through increasing students self-identity as scientists.

We the emergence of covid-19 in 2020, participation in conferences dropped significantly, eventually recovering in 2022. Adjusting to the lack of conferences and reduced interest in participating in conferences, we also supported summer research by 15 undergraduates in 2021. Under the supervision of NSF postdoctoral fellows, students conducted original research and received virtual professional development support, including programs on exploring science careers and applying to graduate school. By generating original research these activities supported Intellectual Merit and through engagement and training of undergraduate scientists, the activities supported Broader Impacts.
